verses.verse: Then Jesus came to the Scribes and Pharisees, who were from Jerusalem saying,
"Why do the disciples break the elders' tradition, for they don't wash their hands when they eat bread?"
But he answered and said to them, "Why do you break God's commandment by your tradition?
"For God commanded saying: «Honor your father and mother,» and «He who curses father and mother, let him die the death.»
"But you say, «Whosoever will say to his father or mother, Whatever might be of a help to you is a dedicated gift already,»
"so not honoring his father or mother. Thus you have nullified God's commandment by your tradition.
"Isaiah did rightly prophesy about you saying,
"This people draw near to me with their mouth and honor me with mouths, but their heart is far from me.
"They worship me manipulatively, teaching men's commandments for doctrine."
And he called to the multitude and said to them, "Hear and understand.
"It is not what goes into the mouth that defiles a man but that which comes out of the mouth--that defiles a man."
Then his disciples came and said to him, "Don't you know that the Pharisees were offended when they heard that saying?"
But he answered and said, "Every plant which my heavenly Father has not planted will be uprooted.
"Let them alone; they are blind leaders of the blind. If the blind lead the blind, both will fall into the ditch."
Then Peter answered and said to him, "Explain this parable to us."
And Jesus said, "Are you still without understanding?
"Don't you understand yet that whatever enters the mouth goes into the stomach comes out in the toilet?
"But those things which come out of the mouth come from the heart; they defile the man.
"For out of the heart comes evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, and blasphemies.
"These are what defile a man but to eat with unwashed hands does not defile a man."
Then Jesus went from there and left for the regions of Tyre and Sidon.
And look, a woman of Canaan came out of the same region and called out to him, saying, "Have mercy on me, O Lord, Son of David, my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil."
But he didn't reply even a word. His disciples came asked him, saying, "Get her out of here, for she keeps calling out to us."
But he answered and said, "I am not sent except to the lost sheep of the House of Israel."
The she came and worshiped him, saying, "Lord, help me."
But he answered, "It is not right to take the children's food and throw it to dogs."
She said, "True Lord, yet the dogs eat the crumbs which fall from their master's table."
The Jesus answered and said to her, "O woman, great is your faith; let it happen to you even as you wish." Her daughter was cured that very hour.
Jesus then left from there and came near the Sea of Galilee and went up into a mountain and sat down there.
And great crowds came to him having with them those [who were] lame, blind, unable to speak, maimed, and many others and laid them down at Jesus' feet, and he healed them.
So much so that the crowds were amazed when they saw those unable to speak speaking, the maimed whole, the lame walking, the blind seeing, and they glorified the God of Israel.

Then Jesus called his disciples and said, "I feel sorry for the crowd, because they have stayed with me now three days and have nothing to eat. I will not send them away not eating, lest they become weak on the road."
His disciples said to him, "Where can we get so much bread in this desolate place so to satisfy such a great crowd?"
Jesus said to them, "How many loaves do you have?" They said, "Seven and a few little fish."
He ordered the crowd to sit down on the ground.
He took the seven loaves and the fish, gave thanks, broke [the food into pieces], and gave it to the disciples, and the disciples [gave] to the crowd.
They all ate, were satisfied, and picked up seven baskets full of the broken [food] that was left.
Those who ate were four thousand men, not counting the women and children.
He sent the crowd away, boarded ship, and came to the coast of Magdala.
